PAGE.TITLE: Introduction to continuity
PAGE.DESCRIPTION:
Roughly speaking a function, $f(x)$, is said to be continuous if small changes in the input result
in small changes in the output. A function is discontinous if there are large jumps in the value of the
function at specific points. There are many subtleties here but as a first intuitive definition we can
write that a function is continuous at $x$ if:
$$
\lim_{\epsilon \rightarrow 0 ) f(x+\epsilon) = \lim_{\epsilon \rightarrow 0 ) f(x-\epsilon)
$$
At any point, $x$, where the above does not hold the function will be discontinuous.

UL.LI: You should be able to sketch examples of continuous and discontinuous functions.
You should be able to explain what we mean by a continuous function.
You should be able to explain what we mean when we say that a function has a discontinuity at $x$.
